title: Redcar steel plant to shut costing 1,700 jobs in major blow to British steelmaking
text:
Its future was cast into doubt last week when it paused production claiming a global plunge in steel prices was to blame. 
The mothballing will lead to 1,700 workers losing their jobs. PA The closure will cost 1,700 jobs 
Today a spokesman for the company said: "SSI UK regret to announce that after a further evaluation and assessment of the situation facing the business, it has concluded they are faced with no other option but to mothball its iron and steel making facilities on Teesside. 
"The Redcar Coke Ovens and the Power Station will continue to operate. 
"This decision has had to be taken against a continuing background of poor steel trading conditions across the globe and the consequential severe deterioration in steel prices experienced during the course of 2015, together with the view that this is unlikely to change in the short term. 
"We will continue to work with various stakeholders, including government, with the objective of restarting operations at Teesside at some point in the future.” Related articles Generous Britain cannot afford this foreign aid budget 
Today a spokesman for the company said: "SSI UK regret to announce that after a further evaluation and assessment of the situation facing the business, it has concluded they are faced with no other option but to mothball its iron and steel making facilities on Teesside. 
"The Redcar Coke Ovens and the Power Station will continue to operate. 
"This decision has had to be taken against a continuing background of poor steel trading conditions across the globe and the consequential severe deterioration in steel prices experienced during the course of 2015, together with the view that this is unlikely to change in the short term. 
"We will continue to work with various stakeholders, including government, with the objective of restarting operations at Teesside at some point in the future.” WARMING IMAGES•REX SHUTTERSTOCK Redcar's steel plant is a major employer 
The company is consulting with trade unions about the jobs cull. 
The GMB union's David Hulse said the closure was 'absolutely devastating'. 
He said: “All that will be left operating will be the coke ovens unless the UK Government steps in even at this stage. It is not too late for them to do so while the furnaces are still burning. 
"GMB will do all in our power to press the case for Government to act and to protect out members and their families." 
Roy Rickhuss, general secretary of the Community union, said: "We had begun to fear the worst over the past few days and this will be devastating news for our members and their families. We will be seeking an urgent meeting with the company to understand the detail of this announcement. We will also be putting in place support for our members in the days and weeks ahead. 
"Steel making on Teesside must have a future and our fight to save our steel will continue." 
Business Minister Anna Soubry blamed economic conditions, including the price of steel halving within the last 12 months. 
She said: "Despite everyone's recent efforts to help SSI this is very sad news and a big blow for the workforce and their families. They are the priority and, with SSI's difficulties being no secret, why I had already asked Amanda Skelton, chief executive of Redcar and Cleveland Borough Council, to chair a local taskforce to help support workers and the local economy. I also have concerns about reports that local contractors have gone unpaid. 
"I hope that SSI's announcement that they are mothballing the furnace gives some hope that steelmaking could be restarted on Teesside in the future." NORTH NEWS & PICTURES LTD Middlesbrough fans protested in favour of Redcar's steel plant SSI have played fast and loose with us for weeks and months. Anna Turley 
Redcar's Labour MP Anna Turley accused SSI of playing "fast and loose" with the plant's future. 
Ms Turley said: "It’s absolutely heartbreaking, it's devastating. It's a huge number of jobs, it's a huge number of livelihoods, but it is more than that to our community. 
"Redcar was built on steelmaking, Teesside was built on steelmaking. It's about generations of people that have worked in that blast furnace and fought so hard, not just in the last few days but in the last few weeks, months, years, to keep steelmaking alive. It's just been allowed to fizzle out. 
"SSI have played fast and loose with us for weeks and months. 
"They cannot be allowed to run the asset into the ground." 
The campaign to keep the steel works alive spread into the local community, with Middlesbrough fans holding up 'Save Our Steel' placards at this weekend's game against Leeds United. Related articles
